ai-mn56:26.5_1: And in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.
ai-mn56:26.6_0: Well then, sirs, I shall give you a simile.
ai-mn56:26.7_0: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.
ai-mn56:27.1_0: Once upon a time there was an old brahmin, elderly and senior. His wife was a young brahmin lady who was pregnant and about to give birth.
ai-mn56:27.2_0: Then she said to the brahmin,
ai-mn56:27.3_0: ‘Go, brahmin, buy a baby monkey from the market and bring it back so it can be a playmate for my child.’
ai-mn56:27.4_0: When she said this, the brahmin said to her,
ai-mn56:27.5_0: ‘Wait, my dear, until you give birth.
ai-mn56:27.6_0: If it’s a girl, I’ll buy a female monkey.
ai-mn56:27.7_0: but if it’s a girl, I’ll buy a female monkey.’
ai-mn56:27.9_0: For a third time, she said,
ai-mn56:27.10_0: ‘Go, brahmin, buy a baby monkey from the market and bring it back so it can be a playmate for my child.’
ai-mn56:27.11_0: Then that brahmin, because of his love for the brahmin lady, bought a male baby monkey at the market, brought it to her, and said,
ai-mn56:27.12_0: ‘I’ve bought this male baby monkey for you so it can be a playmate for your child.’
ai-mn56:27.13_0: When he said this, she said to him,
ai-mn56:27.14_0: ‘Go, brahmin, take this monkey to Rattapāṇi the dyer and approach him.
ai-mn56:27.14_1: and after going, they said this to Rattapāṇi:
ai-mn56:27.15_0: “Mister Rattapāṇi, I wish to have this monkey dyed the color of yellow greasepaint, pounded and re-pounded, and pressed on both sides.”’
ai-mn56:27.16_0: Then that brahmin, because of his love for the brahmin lady, took the monkey to Rattapāṇi the dyer and went to Rattapāṇi the dyer.
ai-mn56:27.16_1: and after approaching he said this to Rattapāṇi:
ai-mn56:27.17_0: ‘Mister Rattapāṇi, I wish to have this monkey dyed the color of yellow greasepaint, pounded and re-pounded, and pressed on both sides.’
ai-mn56:27.18_0: When he said this, Rattapāṇi said to him,
ai-mn56:27.19_0: ‘Sir, this monkey is transparent, using an iron cart, and pressed. It’s their chief.’
ai-mn56:27.20_0: In the same way, the doctrine of the foolish Jains looks fine initially—for fools, not for the astute—but can’t withstand being scrutinized or pressed.
ai-mn56:27.21_0: Then some time later that brahmin took a new pair of garments to Rattapāṇi the dyer.
ai-mn56:27.21_1: and after approaching he said this to Rattapāṇi:
ai-mn56:27.22_0: ‘Mister Rattapāṇi, I wish to have this new pair of garments dyed the color of yellow greasepaint, pounded and re-pounded, and pressed on both sides.’
ai-mn56:27.23_0: When he said this, Rattapāṇi said to him,
ai-mn56:27.24_0: ‘Sir, this pair of garments can withstand a dying, a pounding, and a pressing.’
ai-mn56:27.25_0: In the same way, the doctrine of the Buddha looks fine initially—for the astute, not for fools—and it can withstand being scrutinized and pressed.”

ai-mn56:30.1_0: “But when did you compose these praises of the ascetic Gotama’s beautiful qualities, householder?”
ai-mn56:30.2_0: “Suppose there was a large flower with various flowers and arches of garlands, a creeper pattern, and a sharking mind.

ai-mn56:31.1_0: Unable to bear this honor paid to the Buddha, Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta spewed hot blood from his mouth there and then.
